Story times over

author: infinitelimits00
body:
I usually think most of these posts are troll posts (since people know what wsb is) but seeing your post history, this actually is a legit question. In that case, you should actually go to r/investing or r/stocks. Or r/options if you want to learn about options. We pretty much gamble here not invest. 

The most basic investing advice I would give is to put a fixed amount of money every 2 weeks or each month into an ETF. I would recommend QQQ. If you like individual stocks, look at Microsoft, Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook, Netflix, AMD, Nvidia, Alibaba, Salesforce, Nike, Disney, JNJ, CAT, or another one of those blue chip stocks. I prefer tech though.

That said, you might want to consider putting it into an ETF called **XLK**.  **XLK** is the SPDR Technology Select ETF.  This ETF is 23.9% Apple and 20.3% Microsoft. This means, you'd be investing nearly equal amounts into both of those stocks and that would be almost half of this ETF. This would also help you diversify your holdings a little bit.

author: tranceypants
body:
I’ve worked on building digital platforms and apps for years. Asana, Trello, and Basecamp are the platforms people choose.

It’s not like Teams, Slack, or Discord. Those are like workchatrooms - a more modern mIRC. 

They’re task management platforms. Ideal for project managers and the inherent great part of Asana is using it for remote distributed teams. You can set tasks statuses to be reported on daily/weekly to see your teams progress. It’s a system like Salesforce, once it starts being used, it becomes essential.

author: AngelaQQ
body:
Their balance sheet, cash flows and profit statement are about as bulletproof as they come for a SaaS company, let alone one still in hyper growth stage.

Name any other company with profitable hyper growth.

Their EV/EBITDA is around 500, which is what CRM was around 2010ish.  

CRM never crashed.  Just “grew” into a more reasonable EV/EBITDA. CRM has a “reasonable” EV/EBITDA of around 100 give or take now, which sounds pretty ridiculous still, until you realize this is the new normal, and CRM is on the DJIA.

author: HulksInvinciblePants
body:
>I see the whole "Cloud/AI" craze as a bubble similiar to the 2000 ".COM" bubble. There is potential for cloud/AI to change things, but investors will jump on anything that mentions it without a clear value proposition, in the same way adding ".com" to your company name boosted its valuation.

I agreed with your first point, but not entirely here. First, I absolutely agree cloud is a "buzzword". However, cloud is absolutely going to be critical/beneficial to future business. The problem is many folks still have bizarre notions of what it does (especially when they conflate it with "AI"). There are plenty of cloud operations that are killing it, especially during these pandemic/WFH times. Cloud server/database monitoring tools, cloud collaboration tools, cloud communication platforms, cloud phone routing, cloud analytic tools, cloud CRM platform, cloud security suites, etc. 

Cloud just means removing the need to locally host/maintain these applications. Locally hosted means overhead, personnel, and maintenance. Sometimes is much more lucrative to pay a company a monthly fee, for their proven, web-based service, than to produce/bring something in-house.

author: AngelaQQ
body:
Because they are a software company with global reach.

Let me get that clear.

Microsoft is global. Facebook isn't global. Alibaba isn't global. Google is close to global but is missing a 2 billion chunk of the world's population. None of your SaaS superstars like Snowflake, Cloudflare or even Salesforce are global.

Zoom is global.

There are 4.5 billion internet users in 2020. Lets just say *only* 5 percent of these users use Zoom

5 percent of 4.5 billion is 225 million, which is around the MAU that Zoom itself reported*in April* (200m MAU) They have since doubled that MAU.

There are three ways that Zoom increases revenue. Charging more per paying user (increasing price), increasing usage base, and converting non-paying customers to paying customers. There's ample runway in all three of these paths, and as Zoom is already profitable, it is operating at a tremendous level of operating leverage like a typical fully scaled SaaS company, every additional dollar on the top line is contributing mightily to the bottom line.

Zoom currently being valued at 80x revenues sounds crazy, until you realize a value investor like Warren Buffet just bought into Snowflake at similar p/s metrics.

author: snyder810
body:
If I legit had to do this then GOOGL, LMT, MSFT, MA, & JNJ. No sell rule would have me risk averse and wanting to make picks that will pace with, or close to, the market in a worst case scenario with low risk of a major flame out.

The more fun list:
LRCX - it’s more and more of a tech driven world, they’re an innovative leader helping enable it to happen.

SQ - if they can become what they’re trying to then they’ll be the fin-tech leader in 10 years.

CRM - not only a current leader in the SaaS space, but they’ve consistently made solid acquisitions and great investments. This just seems to be one of the best run companies right now, and I’d wager on them staying one of the growth leaders over the next 5-10 years.

AMZN - History says their growth will slow, but do you really want to bet against their world takeover given only the knowledge we currently have? 

VEEV - I should have bought in years ago, drug trials aren’t stopping and there isn’t currently any meaningful competition for their market. Not only do they have the first mover advantage, I can see it being very sticky even with competitors given the nature of the customer base.

author: zephyy
body:
AWS, GCP, and Azure *do* already offer most of Cloudflare's services. CDN, WAF, serverless functions. I dunno about AWS and GCP but Azure definitely has an equivalent for user / identity authentication (Cloudflare Access).

You have to ask, why do so many people use Cloudflare when the big 3 (and other competitors like Fastly) offer equivalent services? Pricing, ease-of-use.

>Even PaaS like Heroku (owned by Salesforce), runs on AWS resources.

Of course it does, why would it run on Cloudflare? Heroku is for running apps mostly. Cloudflare doesn't have an cloud vm product, why are you bringing them up?

author: oyveyanyday
body:
I don't want to disagree, but I think the past few years haven't been normal trends.  We had a huge correction in late 2018 almost solely based on the fed maybe wanting to increase interest rates.  Tech stocks have soared way above regular valuations and you could have made alot of money this year by selling when the price got super ridiculous and buying back in when the price was just overpriced.  I think the classic "hold forever or you'll get burned" comes from 1) normal economic/social/economic times, 2) when stocks are priced based on valuations.

But we've just been seeing loads of speculation the past few years - Snowflake, Tesla, Uber, Lyft, Beyond Meat, Zoom, Docu, CRM.  I am not sure it makes sense to apply the supposed time tested wisdom with stocks like this especially in 2020, when they are up and down, up and down, up and down

I do think at at some point some of our time-tested wisdom will again become obsolete.  Things change.  In 2020, Warren Buffet's strategy is doing not well, for example

author: Boomtown626
body:
It has to do with how they’re weighted. The dow is only a composite of 30 large companies it has determined best represent the whole of function in the market. (The S&P has 500 companies, nasdaq ha many more, and both have much more exposure to this year’s top performers.) 

The only 5 tech companies it has are MSFT AAPL CRM (those ones have been good) INTC and IBM (ouch). It’s heavier weighted by financials and other stocks that benefit from large crowds of people.

The Dow gets slightly more benefit from reopening stocks, but was largely left behind by this year’s tech runup.

author: jeoportmanteau
body: I can't speak to NET, but my general advice is that if you're holding long term, adding the stock at a premium will be cheap compared to waiting on the sidelines hoping it will drop in price. As for REGI, I invested a couple years ago and since then they have shot up during the lockdowns. I think it's fairly valued finally, but if you want to buy in I wouldn't discourage you. They have so many positive catalysts going for them right now. With higher RIN prices, rejections of oil refinery exemptions from the renewable fuel standard, price target increases, Blender's Tax credits through 2022 and a future renewable diesel plant TBA, I'm still very bullish on this stock long term. Not to mention they could beat earnings in Q3. As for ENPH, I've been doing research on the company and its fundamentals before I invest in them. From what I've learned, the company seems to be rising due to recent analyst upgrades along with positive sentiment for renewables in general. I'd say that long term, clean energy is a great investment and you won't regret buying in even at it's high valuation. My advice, I'd look more towards a mix of clean energy stocks in ICLN or TAN, which will give you exposure to solar stocks broadly.

author: AccomplishedWin2
body:
Regarding ENPH, it seems cool but it may be a bit too exposed to consumers. I have a clean energy ETF position and it grew 20% in the last month and can't go down a lot cuz it's globaly exposed. If you want clean energy ETFs, or even stocks, look for something globaly exposed. 
I don't trust chinesse stocks for the love of my life, so I stay away even from BABA. My friends used to buy from there (I am from EU) and atm they dont anymore due to trust issues regarding the products and if the gov is involved in the business.
SE is cool. I just looked it up and I love it. Everything video games relating is cool af. Shoutout to video games ETFs btw.

author: ixamnis
body:
**QCLN** might be something for you to look at.  **QCLN** is an ETF investing in renewable/clean energy.  The top holdings include:

**NIO** \- 8.58%

**TSLA** \- 6.63%

**SEDG** \- 6.63%  (Solar Edge Technologies) 

**ENPH** \- 5.77%

**ALB** \- 5.27%  (Albemarle Corp)

**RUN**  \- 5.25% (SunRun)

**BEP\_UN:CA** \- 4.45% (Brookfield Partners)

For an online Finance ETF, I'd probably recommend **ARKF**.  The top holdings are:

**SQ** \-12%

**MELI** \- 4.81%

**Z** \- 4.06%

**TECHY** \- 4%

**ICE** \- 3.9%

**SE** \- 3.9%

**PINS** \- 3.7%

**AAPL** \- 3.6%

**TREE** \- 3.5%

&#x200B;

By investing in these 2 funds, you tap into the two sectors you are interested in and the top holdings include the specific companies you want to invest in.  **QCLN** is both an EV and a clean energy sector, as opposed to **ICLN**, **TAN** and **FAN** which include only renewable energy companies but not EV companies.

Investment firms have prices ranging from 60-100 so I don’t know how much buying pressure is left at this point.  The runup was fierce but my thesis is that money is moving out of oil.  ENPH and FSLR and some other solar companies are in MM sight.

author: Mad_Nekomancer
body:
SFTBY gets mocked a lot by but they have a ton of cash right now and have more share buy-backs to go, and even a few months into a share buy-back program trade at a huge discount relative to their assets. Price might drop a bit if the Arm sale falls though but it's still a quality asset. Vision Fund 2 acquisitions are in progress and seem focused on higher tech stuff than the last one. 

BABA share value seems to have everything Trump can throw at it priced in, so I think it's a good buy whether long or short term. If the Ant IPO meets expectations the BABA price will rise for sure. 

I'm still looking to add green energy stocks. PLUG was up today, and ENPH was close to unchanged after having a good couple weeks. 

JPM is one I'm looking to buy at anything below $90 if it gets that low. 

MSGS seems like a good candidate for a nice return if you're willing to buy and hold 18 months or so.

author: nova46
body: ENPH has been doing wonderful lately. I am so pissed I sold my whole position a few months ago when the stock tanked due to fraud accusations. I bought back in recently and am up 35% already, but I would have been up almost 100% had I just held my original position.

author: Thefishman1
body:
Well ENPH  produces a very important product that is essential to the production of solar panels (micro inverters) they are continuously growing and doing better and better year over year,  EPS went from -.54 to 1.38 in two years (2019,) forbes) 

ICLN is a good all rounder that covers the solar energy sector in general, and also gives me exposure to ENPH for not 70$ a share ( which, not having much cash to invest, I'll take)

NET because technology is advancing at a very rapid rate, and when they went down a while ago, almost half the internet went down. They have services for free currently that will be paying in the future as well, and although they arent profitable yet, they will slowly get there.

author: sunshinelighter
body:
Hi 👋! Been in $ENPH since February 2019 when it was in single-digits and today, we hit the ATH.  


We have faced a few short hit pieces for ENPH in the past year, and each time, it turned out to be great buying opportunities. There is no doubt that this company is a $100+/share company and with the upcoming earnings, it'll most likely be a solid run. The demand can't keep up with the supply, if you listen to the last earnings call.

&#x200B;

Long term, trust the company, and trust Badri. If anything, this will retrace in the coming weeks, before blowing past for the earnings.

author: sunshinelighter
body:
I'm betting everything on ENPH to succeed in the long term. The lineup for their technology and what they have coming in the pipeline is certainly going to be taking larger market share away from SEDG.   


I love SEDG, but I love ENPH a little more. Both investments won't go wrong though.

author: Grymninja
body:
I love all the main solar stocks and own a bit of all of them (majority ENPH though). I agree SEDG and ENPH definitely have more growth potential than residential focused companies like RUN. Even with an assumed Biden victory and solar tax credits, I don't understand RUNs valuation.

I almost want to jump out now because I think it has to correct soon. Or maybe it will just run on hype through October? Ugh

author: SaveThemTurdles
body:
I’m holding all my solar stocks. I think they have the most promise long term, regardless of the election. 

SEDG and ENPH both are leaders in the solar inverter manufacturing, with each company making a different type of inverter. Both very innovative companies as well trying to bring down costs of energy storage and transportation. TAN has SEDG and ENPH in the top 3 holdings if you like a less risky solar option.

author: GenTelGuy
body:
Both are good - they differ in balance sheet like you mentioned and in their tech. ENPH is microinverters sold on a per-panel basis whereas SEDG inverters are larger devices meant for handling your whole array. 

This video talks about the differences between the products: https://youtu.be/hKRCGzz6-Ws

ENPH, SEDG, FSLR, I really think it's just a matter of having as much of all of them as possible.
